optionalFeatureTypes.DZC:T:TnK: Rogue Rework; Talents: Tools and Kits

tools: Choose one type of the following: {@item alchemist's supplies|phb}, {@item disguise kit|phb}, {@item posioner's kit|phb}, {@item thieves' tools|phb}, one {@item gaming set|phb} of your choice, or one {@item musical instrument|phb} of your choice

default: (a) a {@item shortbow}, {@item quiver}, and {@item arrows (20)|phb|20 arrows} or (b) two {@filter melee weapons|items|source=phb|category=basic|type=melee weapon}
(a) {@item alchemist's supplies|phb}, (b) {@item disguise kit|phb}, or (c) {@item thieves' tools|phb}
(a) a {@item gaming set|phb} or (b) a {@item musical instrument|phb}
(a) a {@item burglar's pack|phb}, (b) a {@item dungeoneer's pack|phb}, or (c) an {@item explorer's pack|phb}

tools: Choose one type of the following: {@item alchemist's supplies|phb}, {@item disguise kit|phb}, {@item posioner's kit|phb}, {@item thieves' tools|phb}, one {@item gaming set|phb} of your choice, or one {@item musical instrument|phb} of your choice

classFeature.name: Reliable Partner
entries: Starting at 1st level, you can outperform anyone if you take your time to do things well. If you spend at least 10 minutes performing a task, you gain a +5 bonus to the ability check you make for it.

Beginning at 15th level, your skills have improved considerably to the point you only need to spend at least 1 minute performing a task to gain the bonus. This bonus increases to +10 if you spend at least 10 minutes performing a task.

classFeature.name: Reliable Partner improvement
entries: At 15th level, you only need to spend at least 1 minute performing a task to gain the bonus. This bonus increases to +10 if you spend at least 10 minutes performing a task.

classFeature.name: Roguish Talents
entries: Be it luck or a natural gift, you have a talent for succeeding in whatever you want. At 1st level, you have a pool of luck represented by a number of d6s, as shown in the Talent Pool column of the Rogue table. This pool is known as your Talent die.

entries.name: Talents
entries: A talent is an ability that allows you to spend your pool of d6s in particular ways. You begin having two {@filter talents|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:T} of your choice. Your {@filter talents|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:T} are detailed at the end of the class description. When you gain certain rogue levels, you acquire additional talents of your choice, as shown in the Acquired Talents column of the Rogue table.

When you use a talent, you can spend a number of d6s from your pool equal to half your proficiency bonus (rounded up) or less. Roll the spent die and add them to the die roll associated to your talent. You regain all of your expended die when you finish a short or long rest.
Whenever you gain a level in this class, you can replace a talent you have with another one.

classFeature.name: Underhanded Tactics
entries: In order to survive in a harsh, competitive environment, you worked on your dirty tricks, known as {@filter Underhanded Tactics|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:UT}. The number of underhanded tactics you know is shown in the Known Tactics column of the Rogue table.

classFeature.name: Underhanded Tactics improvement
entries: At 7th level, you learn an additional {@filter Underhanded Tactic|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:UT} of your choice.

classFeature.name: Underhanded Tactics improvement
entries: At 14th level, you learn an additional {@filter Underhanded Tactic|optionalfeatures|feature type=DZC:CS} of your choice.

classFeature.name: Cunning Action
entries: At 2nd level, your quick thinking and agility allow you to move and act quickly. You can take the {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, {@action Help}, {@action Hide}, or {@action Use an Object} action as a bonus action.

classFeature.name: Cheaper Craft
entries: It's important to make do with what little you have. At 2nd level, you learn how to craft certain items using cheaper materials. When you are crafting either a nonmagical or consumable item, you can reduce its material cost by a percentage equal to 15 times your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 5 percent). However, by doing so you sacrifice the item's quality. Thus, any item you craft in this way lasts for 24 hours and sells for a quarter of its selling price. After that time, the item breaks or loses potency, and the materials can't be reclaimed.

classFeature.name: Roguish Vocation
entries: At 3rd level, you dedicate to a vocation that helps you compete in the market, all detailed at the end of the class description. Your archetype grants you features at 3rd level and again at 9th, 13th, and 17th level.

classFeature.name: Roguish Vocation feature
entries: At 9th level, you gain a feature granted by your Roguish Vocation.

classFeature.name: Roguish Vocation feature
entries: At 13th level, you gain a feature granted by your Roguish Vocation.

classFeature.name: Roguish Vocation feature
entries: At 17th level, you gain a feature granted by your Roguish Vocation.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: At 3rd level, choose two of your proficiencies, either in skills or with tools. Your proficiency bonus is doubled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.
At 10th level, you can choose two more of your skill or tool proficiencies to gain this benefit.

classFeature.name: Expertise
entries: At 10th level, you can choose two more of your skill or tool proficiencies to gain this benefit.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 4th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 6th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 8th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 10th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 12th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 16th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Ability Score Improvement
entries: When you reach 20th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
If your DM allows the use of feats, you may instead take a {@5etools feat|feats.html}.

classFeature.name: Swift Consumption
entries: At 5th level, your fast hands can quickly activate certain magical items. You can use your Cunning Action to use a consumable magic item as a bonus action, such as potions or spell scrolls. The rarity of the item can't be greater than uncommon. You can use rare items with this feature at 11th level, and very rare ones at 18th level.

classFeature.name: Swift Consumption improvement
entries: At 11th level you can use rare items with this feature.

classFeature.name: Swift Consumption improvement
entries: At 11th level you can use very rare items with this feature.

classFeature.name: Quick Learner
entries: Also at 5th level, you can prepare for any situation you might face in the short future. During a long rest, you can spend 1 hour learning how to use a skill or tool you have no proficiency with. At the end of the long rest, you add your proficiency bonus to checks using that skill or tool you studied. This benefit lasts until you use this feature again or you gain proficiency in the respective skill or tool.

entries.name: The Quick Learner Effect
entries: When imported via Plutonium, the feature will create an effect in you character sheet to add this benefit to a skill and a tool. By default it is set to add your proficiency bonus to your Acrobatics skill, and no bonus to your thieves' tools, you can manually modify it according to your choices.

entries.name: Skills' Abbreviations
entries: The following is a list with all the skill's abbreviations found in the FoundryVTT software, in parenthesis is the skill it corresponds to: acr (Acrobatics), ani (Animal Handling), arc (Acrobatics), ath (Athletics), dec (Deception), his (History), ins (Insight), itm (Intimidation), inv (Investigation), med (Medicine), nat (Nature), prc (Perception), prf (Performance), per (Persuasion), rel (Religion), slt (Sleight of Hands), ste (Stealth), sur (Survival).

entries.name: Tools' Abbreviations
entries: The following is a list with all the tool's abbreviations found in the FoundryVTT software, in parenthesis is the tool it corresponds to: art (artisan's tools), alchemist, brewer, calligrapher, carpenter, cartographer, coobler, cook, glassblower, jeweler, leatherworker, mason, painter, potter, smith, tinker, weaver, woodcarver, disg (disguise kit), forg (forgery kit), game (gaming set), chess (chess set), dice (dice set), card (playing cards set), herb (herbalism kit), music (musical instrument), bagpipes, drum, dulcimer, flute, horn, lute, lyre, panflute, shawm, viol, navg (navigator's tools), pois (poisoner's kit), thief (thieves' tools), vehicle (vehicles), air (air vehicle), land (vehicle), space (space vehicle), water (water vehicle)

classFeature.name: Shared Misfortune
entries: Bad luck always strikes at the worst possible time, unless it happens to someone else. At 7th level, whenever a creature that you can see within 30 feet from you makes an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw, you can give the creature disadvantage on the roll. When you do so, you can't use this feature again before the start of your next turn.

classFeature.name: Opportunity for Improvement
entries: No matter how dire the situation is, you can always count on your talent to fix it. Starting at 14th level, when you roll for initiative and have no Talent die remaining, you regain two Talent die. You also regain one Talent die when you fail an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw on your turn.

classFeature.name: Mastery
entries: At 19th level, choose two of your proficiencies, either in skills or with tools. Your proficiency bonus is tripled for any ability check you make that uses either of the chosen proficiencies.

entries.name: The Mastery Effect
entries: When imported via Plutonium, the feature will create an effect in you character sheet to add this benefit to a skill and a tool. By default it is set to add double your proficiency bonus to your Acrobatics skill and your thieves' tools, you can manually modify it according to your choices.

entries.name: Skills' Abbreviations
entries: The following is a list with all the skill's abbreviations found in the FoundryVTT software, in parenthesis is the skill it corresponds to: acr (Acrobatics), ani (Animal Handling), arc (Acrobatics), ath (Athletics), dec (Deception), his (History), ins (Insight), itm (Intimidation), inv (Investigation), med (Medicine), nat (Nature), prc (Perception), prf (Performance), per (Persuasion), rel (Religion), slt (Sleight of Hands), ste (Stealth), sur (Survival).

entries.name: Tools' Abbreviations
entries: The following is a list with all the tool's abbreviations found in the FoundryVTT software, in parenthesis is the tool it corresponds to: art (artisan's tools), alchemist, brewer, calligrapher, carpenter, cartographer, coobler, cook, glassblower, jeweler, leatherworker, mason, painter, potter, smith, tinker, weaver, woodcarver, disg (disguise kit), forg (forgery kit), game (gaming set), chess (chess set), dice (dice set), card (playing cards set), herb (herbalism kit), music (musical instrument), bagpipes, drum, dulcimer, flute, horn, lute, lyre, panflute, shawm, viol, navg (navigator's tools), pois (poisoner's kit), thief (thieves' tools), vehicle (vehicles), air (air vehicle), land (vehicle), space (space vehicle), water (water vehicle)

classFeature.name: Stroke of Luck
entries: At 20th level, you have an uncanny knack for succeeding when you need to. Before you make an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw, you can treat the d20 roll as a 20.
You can use this feature three times, you regain all expended uses when you finish a long rest.
In addition, when you finish a long rest, you can choose one of your acquired talents and replace it with a different one.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: Before you make an ability check, attack roll, or saving throw

optionalfeature.name: Ganging Up
entries: It's easier to mess someone up when your gang's with you, and you're less likely to be messed with. If you and at least 2 friendly creatures are within 10 feet of the same creature, and no other hostile creature is within 10 feet from you and your companions, then your group has advantage on {@skill Intimidation} and {@skill Persuasion} checks, and advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} against the surrounded target.

optionalfeature.name: Parkour
entries: You honed your skills to climb and move across buildings to evade authorities and thugs. Climbing doesn't cost you extra movement, the number of feet you can cover with a long jump increases by 10 feet, and you reduce the damage you take from falling an amount equal to your rogue level.

optionalfeature.name: Pickpocketing
entries: No purse is safe from you. You take no penalty to your checks for trying to {@action Steal|DZC:ANA:Ro|steal} a closely guarded object, as long as the object wouldn't be extremely noticeable or time consuming to remove (like worn shoes or armor, or wielded objects).

optionalfeature.name: Scamming
entries: You make use of your wits to take advantage of the gullible and the naive, convincing them of how your products are of a higher quality than any other. You have advantage on Charisma checks whenever you attempt to sell an item or your services for a higher price than the one normally offered.

optionalfeature.name: Seduction
entries: There is no denying that it's easier to get what you want by enamouring your audience than taking it by force. Seduction is an art that can be performed in many ways, some of the most common ones are by flirting, sweet talking, courting, or simply flaunting your physical attractiveness. If you spend at least 10 minutes seducing a creature, you have advantage on your next convince check against it.

optionalfeature.name: Sneaking
entries: Your technique is to hide in less visible places in order to escape tough situations, like blending with crowds, ducking behind crates, or stepping into the shadows. You can attempt to hide from a creature when you are lightly obscured or behind three-quarters cover from it.

optionalfeature.name: Academical
entries: You can spend your Talent die on Intelligence checks related to academical research or memory.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you make an Intelligence check related to academical research or memory

optionalfeature.name: Athletic
entries: You can spend your Talent die on Strength checks related to climbing, jumping, running, or swimming.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you make a Strength check related to climbing, jumping, running, or swimming

optionalfeature.name: Endurance
entries: You can spend your Talent die on Constitution checks related to enduring adverse conditions. For instance, going without sleep, surviving without food or water, being exposed to extreme temperatures, or resisting intoxication.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you make a Constitution check related to enduring adverse conditions

optionalfeature.name: Exploration
entries: You can spend your Talent die on checks related to navigating through an area of wilderness, dungeons, or cities, such as avoid getting lost, finding resources or sustenance, or learning about its history or inhabitants.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you make a check related to navigating through an area of wilderness, dungeons, or cities

optionalfeature.name: Feline Grace
entries: You can spend your Talent die on Dexterity checks related to coordinating your movements, avoid falling, and hiding.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you make a Dexterity check related to coordinating your movements, avoid falling, and hiding

optionalfeature.name: Medical
entries: You can spend your Talent die on Wisdom checks related to treating wounds or identifying common diseases.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you make a Wisdom check related to treating wounds or identifying common diseases

optionalfeature.name: Searching
entries: You can spend your Talent die on ability checks related to looking for creatures, objects, traps, or clues.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you make an ability check related to looking for creatures, objects, traps, or clues

optionalfeature.name: See Through
entries: You can spend your Talent die on checks related to examining for illusions or someone trying to deceive you.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you make an ability check related to examining for illusions or someone trying to deceive you

optionalfeature.name: Theatrics
entries: You can spend your Talent die on Charisma checks related to convincing or deceiving a creature, or performing an act.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: When you make a Charisma check related to convincing or deceiving a creature, or performing an act

optionalfeature.name: Body Balance
entries: You can spend your Talent die on saving throws against being {@condition grappled}, pushed, or knocked {@condition prone}.

optionalfeature.name: Mental Resistance
entries: You can spend your Talent die on Intelligence and Wisdom saving throws against magic.

optionalfeature.name: Physical Fortitude
entries: You can spend your Talent die on Strength and Constitution saving throws against magic.

optionalfeature.name: Resistant Body
entries: You can spend your Talent die on saving throws against poisons and diseases.

optionalfeature.name: Trap Connoisseur
entries: You can spend your Talent die on saving throws against traps.

optionalfeature.name: Trickster
entries: You can spend your Talent die on Dexterity and Charisma saving throws against magic.

optionalfeature.name: Unwavering Heart
entries: You can spend your Talent die on saving throws against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}.

optionalfeature.name: Alchemy
entries: When you use {@item alchemist's supplies|phb} to craft a dose of {@item acid (vial)|phb|acid} acid or {@item alchemist's fire|phb}, you can spend your Talent die to increase the initial damage of that item by an amount equal to the total rolled. This extra damage lasts for 24 hours after the item is crafted.

foundrySystem.rsr5e.quickDamage.context.0: Bonus to acid (vial) or alchemist's fire initial damage

optionalfeature.name: Disguising
entries: While wearing a disguise you made using a {@item disguise kit|phb} and a creature tries to see through it, you can spend your Talent die and increase the DC for that check by the total rolled.

optionalfeature.name: Gaming
entries: Using a {@item gaming set|phb} you can spend one day gambling or performing a show with it. Spend your Talent die. Roll a d20 at the end of the day. Add your proficiency bonus to the roll if you have proficiency with that tool. If you roll a 15 or higher, you gain an amount of sp equal to the total rolled in your Talent die. If you are gambling, you lose that amount of sp if you fail the check, and double the amount you win if you roll a 20 or higher.

foundrySystem.rsr5e.quickDamage.context.0: Amount of sp for this activity

optionalfeature.name: Musical
entries: When you are performing a show in a public place using a {@item musical instrument|phb}, and your performance succeeds on captivating the public, you can spend your Talent die. You gain a number of fans equal to the total rolled.

entries.name: What if a Fan?
entries: Fans are creatures who are friendly to you, and might offer some goods or services to you with almost no cost in return. The fan will assist you as much as a reasonable person would assist someone they admired. However, if a fan is {@condition charmed}, they might be convinced to go beyond, even if it costs them dearly.

optionalfeature.name: Poisoning
entries: When you craft a {@item basic poison (vial)|phb|vial of basic poison} with a {@item poisoner's kit|phb}, you can spend your Talent die to improve its potency. When you do so, the first creature affected by that poison will take a penalty to the next ability check, saving throw, or attack roll it makes before the next minute. The penalty equals the total rolled on your Talent die. The poison retains this additional effect for 24 hours after it's crafted.

optionalfeature.name: Tending Wounds
entries: When you use a {@item healer's kit|phb} on a creature, you can spend your Talent die to give the creature temporary hit points equal to the total rolled. These temporary hit points last for 10 minutes.

optionalfeature.name: Thievery
entries: You can spend your Talent die whenever you use {@item thieves' tools|phb} to successfully unlock a treasure chest, a door to a trasure room, or other type of receptacle that contains loot. If you do, you find a number of gp within that treasure equal to the total rolled in your Talent die.

optionalfeature.name: Aiming
entries: If you haven't moved on your turn and make a ranged weapon attack, you can spend your Talent die and add it to the attack roll. After you use this talent, your speed is 0 and can't use it again before the end of your turn.

optionalfeature.name: Blocking
entries: When you take damage, you can use your reaction to spend your Talent die and reduce the damage taken by the total rolled.

optionalfeature.name: Cutting
entries: When you hit a creature with a weapon attack and have advantage on the attack roll, you can spend your Talent die on the attack's damage roll.

You don't need advantage on the attack roll if another creature is distracting the target (like when using the {@action Help|phb} or {@action Distract|DZC:ANA:Ro} action) and you don't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

optionalfeature.name: Dodging
entries: When a creature that you can see targets you with an attack, you can use your reaction to spend your Talent die and add it to your AC against that attack.

optionalfeature.name: Striking
entries: If you target a creature with a melee weapon attack and no other creature is within 5 feet from you or the target, you can spend your Talent die and add it to the attack roll.

optionalfeature.name: Trapping
entries: When you are setting up a trap that deals damage when activated, you can spend your Talent die and add it to that trap's damage. This effect lasts for 1 hour before it's activated.

subclassFeature.name: Thief
entries: Everything comes to he who waits, but quicker yet to he who takes! Such is the law of all thieves. Some do it for the thrill of a challenging robbery, some are driven by greed, and others believe they are distributing the wealths of the world.
These rogues often operate as burglars, bandits, and even cutpurses. They can steal coins from a purse or a jewel from a high security chamber, all without leaving a clue.

subclassFeature.name: Fast Hands
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with {@item thieves' tools|phb} if you don't already have it. In addition, you can use your {@classFeature Cunning Action|Rogue Rework|DZC:ANA:Ro|2|DZC:ANA:Ro} to take the {@action Steal|DZC:ANA:Ro} action or use thieves' tools to disable a trap as a bonus action.

subclassFeature.name: Pickpocket Veteran
entries: Also at 3rd level, you learn the {@optfeature Pickpocketing|DZC:ANA:Ro} tactic, or another one of your choice if you already know it. This tactic doesn't count against the number of tactics you know. In addition, you can also attempt to steal from creatures that are in combat or alert, but you take a –5 penalty to your check.

subclassFeature.name: Sneaky Thief
entries: At 9th level, a creature you are hidden from takes a -5 penalty to its {@skill Perception} check when you attempt to {@action Steal|DZC:ANA:Ro|steal}, unless the creature is in combat or alert.

subclassFeature.name: Mug
entries: At 13th level, once on your turn, when you deal damage to a creature within your reach using a weapon attack made with your {@action Attack} action, you can take the {@action Steal|DZC:ANA:Ro} action against that target as part of the same action. You take no penalty to your checks for trying to steal from that creature until the end of your turn.

subclassFeature.name: Legendary Thief
entries: At 17th level, you are capable of stealing anything in front of everyone's eyes. You can attempt to {@action Steal|DZC:ANA:Ro|steal} an object that is wielded, or that would be extremely noticeable or time consuming to remove. However, this takes you time to perform depending on how difficult it is to remove the object, which is usually 1 minute (armor for example takes significantly longer). Throughout this duration you must have some means of staying hidden, such as being inside a heavily obscured area.
When you do this, you take a –5 penalty to your check and observers will immediatly notice the object is gone after you steal it if it's extremely noticeable (like a full plate armor).

subclassFeature.name: Assassin
entries: Strike first and deadly. This is the motto of assassins, a workforce that operates from under the eyes. Their tactic revolves around efficiency, killing their target before giving room for persecution.

These rogues can be found in many places, ranging from governamental positions as the king's private assassins, through priests who exterminate enemies of their church, to hitmans from the underworld.

subclassFeature.name: Poison Adept
entries: Starting at 3rd level, you gain proficiency with the {@item poisoner's kit|phb} if you don't already have it. Any poison you craft using poisoner's kit has a bonus to its saving throw DC and damage equal to your Intelligence modifier (minimum of 1), and it ignores resistance to poison damage.

subclassFeature.name: Easy Dispatch
entries: You can get an easy kill on weakened enemies, more so if you are faster than them. At 3rd level, on your first turn of combat, you have advantage on attack rolls against any creature that hasn't taken a turn yet.

In addition, if you hit with a weapon attack a creature that is {@condition incapacitated}, {@condition poisoned}, surprised, or that can't see you, you can spend up to three d6s from your talent pool and add it to the attack's damage roll.

subclassFeature.name: Incapacitate
entries: At 9th level, you have a way to secure a kill, in case the first blow wasn't enough. On your first turn of combat, if you hit with a weapon attack a creature that hasn't taken a turn yet, it must succeed on a Constitution saving throw or become {@condition incapacitated} until the end of your next turn. The DC equals 10 or half the damage the creature takes, whichever number is higher.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: On your first turn of combat, if you hit with a weapon attack a creature that hasn't taken a turn yet

subclassFeature.name: Potent Poison
entries: At 13th level, creatures have disadvantage on the first saving throw they make against a poison crafted by you.
Additionally, a creature {@condition poisoned} by you takes 3d6 poison damage at the end of each of its turns. This damage increases by 1d6 for each consecutive turn it remains {@condition poisoned}.

subclassFeature.name: Assassinate
entries: Starting at 17th level, you become a master of instant death. If you target a creature with your {@subclassFeature Incapacitate|Rogue Rework|DZC:ANA:Ro|Assassin|DZC:ANA:Ro|9|DZC:ANA:Ro}, you can use this feature to make that attack more devastating. If you do, the creature is reduced to 0 hit points if it fails the saving throw against Incapacitate, and it becomes {@condition incapacitated} and vulnerable to all damage until the end of your next turn on a successful save.
Once you use this feature, you can't use it again on the same creature for the next 24 hours.

foundrySystem.activation.condition: On your first turn of combat, if you hit with a weapon attack a creature that hasn't taken a turn yet

action.name: Convince
entries: As an action, you attempt to manipulate a creature into thinking what you want it to think. Choose a creature within 30 feet from you that can see or hear you. Make a Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) or Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check (your choice) contested by the target's Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check. If you have done anything harmful to the creature within the last minute, you have disadvantage on your check. If you succeed, the creature will be swayed to your point of view to a reasonable degree. This can also cause the creature to turn friendly, indifferent, or hostile towards certain creatures, either of your or the DM's choice. Your DM has the final judgement on what the creature will do or how it will behave.

action.name: Disable
entries: As an action, you attempt to momentarily disable one of a creature's senses, be it throwing debris at its eyes, making a deafening noise next to its ears, or dishing out a dirty attack to its eyes or ears. Choose a creature within your reach that is no more than one size larger than you. You can either target its eyes or ears, if it has any. The creature must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity or Constitution saving throw (its choice) or become {@condition blinded} or {@condition deafened} until the start of your next turn, if you targeted the eyes or ears, respectively.

action.name: Distract
entries: As an action, you do everything you can to distract one creature that you can see. Until the start of your next turn, while that creature is within 5 feet from you and you aren't {@condition incapacitated}, your target has disadvantage on attack rolls against targets other than you, and disadvantage on {@skill Perception} checks.

action.name: Intimidate
entries: As an action, you attempt to intimidate a creature. Choose a creature within 30 feet from you that can see or hear you. Make a Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) check contested by the target's Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check. If you succeed, the target is {@condition frightened} of you until the start of your next turn.

action.name: Steal
entries: As an action, you try to take a Small object without being noticed, which usually requires at least one free hand. The object you are trying to steal can be unsecured, worn or carried, but it can't weight more than half a pound, and it mustn't be extremely noticeable or difficult to remove (like worn clothes or armor, or wielded objects).

To steal an object you must make a Dexterity ({@skill Sleight of Hands}) check against the Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check of any observer in the area (passive Perception if they aren't in combat or alert), including the creature you are trying to steal from (if any). An observer sees you if it succeeds on the check. If the object is unsecured, you take it regardless of this result. If you fail on the check against the creature you are trying to steal from, you also fail to take the object. You also automatically fail the check against the creature you are trying to steal from if it's in combat or alert.
If the object is closely guarded (like inside a pocket or a sheathed weapon), you take a penalty to your Sleight of Hands check, usually a -5 penalty.

entries.name: Rogue
entries: The halfling signals her companions to wait, then scouts the dungeon ahead on her own, disabling a potential trap and unlocking the door at the end of the hallway with her thieves' tools. After making sure there were no sounds to be heard from the other side, she steps into the darkness to hide and signals her teammates to procede forward.

Causing an uproar in the tavern for cheating on a card game, the goblin is immediatly surrounded by a group of violent drunks. However, he is well experienced in getting out of this predicament. He pulls out a harmonica from his pants and starts playing a catchy tune that slowly but surely shifts the mood of the place, enticing everyone to join the song, wether by complimenting the music or dancing. Once everyone has forgotten about the little fella's misdeed, he flees with a purse filled with the sap's money.

The unsuspecting group eats the food provided by the nice lady. Suddenly everyone falls unconscious on their plates. The lady then takes her time to cage each one of them, realizing too late one of them is missing. It's none other than the half-elf, who was faking being affected by the poison, waiting for the second the lady wasn't looking to make her escape. Enraged, she tries to pursue her, only to fall victim to a trap that renders her motionless. As she tries to escape, the half-elf jumps in to inject her with her own poison, making her fall unconscious. She cages her and releases her friends, waiting for them to wake up to leave together.

Rogues exploit their talents to get the upper hand in any situation. They have a knack for finding the solution to just about any problem, demonstrating a resourcefulness and versatility that is the cornerstone of any successful adventuring party.

entries.name: Skill and Precision
entries: Rogues devote much more effort mastering the use of a variety of skills than perfecting their combat abilities, obtaining a broad expertise that few other characters can match. Many rogues focus on stealth and deception, while others refine the skills that help them in a dungeon environment, such as climbing, finding and disarming traps, and opening locks.

When it comes to combat, rogues prioritize cunning over brute strength. They avoid danger, placing themselves in safe positions, using their quickness to aid the party by creating openings for them to attack the enemy and ensuring fail-safes to maximize their chances to win. Although, some rogues do acquire abilities that make them capable foes, like precise and powerful attacks, or evading mortal blows.

entries.name: A Shady Living
entries: Rogues commonly originate from cities and lawless lands, usually from a necessity to survive in a hostile environment, one where you have to compete for food, watch your back at every corner, lie to live another die, and even kill for a couple copper coins. Thus, they have to learn every trick they can to survive. More often than not they form big groups and organizations to protect themselves, like thieves' guilds, crime families, or a band of outlaws.

In other cases, rogues are born from professions that require advanced skills and the will to get their hands dirty, such as spies, assassins, investigators, treasure hunters, exterminators, locksmiths, or ambassadors.

As adventurers, rogues fall on both sides of the law. Some are hardened criminals who decide to seek their fortune in treasure hoards, while others take up a life of adventure to escape from the law. Some have learned and perfected their skills with the explicit purpose of infiltrating ancient ruins and hidden crypts in search of treasure.

entries.name: Creating a Rogue
entries: As you create your rogue character, consider the character's relationship to the law. Do you have a criminal past—or present? Are you on the run from the law or an organization that swore a vendetta on you? Did you leave your previous profession due to complications with your employers or to escape a monotonous routine in search of a more fulfilling life? Are you driven by greed or some other desire?

What was the trigger that led you away from your previous life? Did a heist gone terribly wrong cause you to reevaluate your career? Maybe a successful robbery gave you the coin needed to escape the squalor of your life. Did wanderlust finally call you away from your home? Perhaps you suddenly found yourself cut off from your family or your mentor, and you had to find a new means of support. Could it be that you have an unfinished business causing you sleepless nights? Or maybe you made a new friend—another member of your adventuring party—who showed you new possibilities for earning a living and employing your particular talents.

entries.name: Quick Build
entries: You can make a rogue quickly by following these suggestions. First, make Dexterity your highest ability score. Your next-highest should be Charisma if you plan to emphasize on social interactions or Intelligence if you want to focus on discovery and plan to adopt a magical subclass. Second, choose the charlatan background.

entries.name: Can I add this Bonus?
entries: Sometimes an ability, feature, or spell allows you to add a bonus to an attack roll, ability check, or saving throw, such as the bard's Bardic Inspiration, a war cleric's  Channel Divinity: Guided Strike, the *bless* spell, the martial technique boost offensive, and many others. Other abilities allow you to reroll the die for those die rolls, such as the drunken master monk's Drunkard's Luck. There is another type of abilities, much rarer than the others, ones that allow you to add special effects to your actions, reactions, die rolls, etc., such as the monk's Evasion ki feature. These abilities have in common the lack of key words for its trigger, such as hit, succeed, miss, or fail, which is why you can choose to use these after seeing the roll, but before the DM says wether the roll succeeds or fails.

entries.name: Changes to Unarmed Strikes and the Finesse Property
entries: In this compendium unarmed strikes and the finesse property suffer important changes meant to keep balance in check.

entries.name: Finesse Property
entries: The property now allows to choose between your Strength or Dexterity modifier only for the attack roll with the weapon, but not for the damage roll. For the damage roll you still have to use your Strength modifier for melee weapon attacks or your Dexterity modifier for ranged weapon attacks.

entries.name: Unarmed Strikes
entries: Unarmed strikes are now considered to have the finesse and light properties.

entries.name: Additional Actions
entries: You can incorporate the following actions into your game: {@action Convince|DZC:ANA:Ro}, {@action Disable|DZC:ANA:Ro}, {@action Distract|DZC:ANA:Ro}, {@action Intimidate|DZC:ANA:Ro}, and {@action Steal|DZC:ANA:Ro}
